text: the most important thing about the
Stonewall riots or Rebellion depending
on which terminology you use uh is that
it creates An Origin myth it gives gay
people LGBT people An Origin myth and
all social movements need to understand
and to acknowledge and identify their
point of origin and so for us it's
Stonewall uh one of the things that I
think this does is a gives us a kind of
collective sense of identity that we all
come from with the spirit of rebellion
emerged in this place that we can
identify it's tangible we can see it we
visited it we visited over the weekend
here at the 40th anniversary and so it's
a place we all know um even if we
weren't all there the other but the
other flip side of that the problem with
that is that it it then uh makes it seem
as if history is divided into everything
that happened before Stonewall and
everything that happened afterwards as
if history is kind of neatly divided
according to this sort of point of
origin and I think one of the things
that that's done uh frankly in the
public imagination and in the LGBT
community as it understands its history
uh is that it it it diminishes the
efforts often quiet often invisible
often full of real struggle of what
really did happen before this kind of
explosive origin of the modern gay
rights movement or Gay Liberation and
there were decades uh if not centuries
of struggles that um that LGBT people
even if they weren't called lesbian gay
bisexual or transgendered at the time
that they went through to establish and
live lives of dignity against forces of
great oppression and discrimination uh
and in particular the couple of decades
before the late 60s uh the 40s and 50s
and and early 60s was a period of great
mobilization of great organizing uh of
the establishment of our first
newspapers and our print culture uh The
Establishment and founding of our first
bars our political organizations the
first even public protests there were
public protests against discrimination
in federal employment and in federal
agencies and in the military uh long
before the folks rose up at Stonewall in
June of 1969 and so one of the things
that I seek to do as a historian and
there are many historians who have
written about this uh John demilio and
and George chony uh Estelle fredman many
many historians and Scholars have
written about this history uh but it
hasn't taken hold yet I don't think in
the broad public imagination not even
even within the LGBT community and
certainly Beyond it uh this history is
not known one of the things that I've
been talking about recently to my
students and to uh my colleagues is that
you know before the the all of the media
attention around the 40th anniversary of
Stonewall that has gotten some political
attention too recently with Obama
inviting uh activists and leaders to the
white house uh is that you know if you
had asked six months ago uh if you had
taken an public opinion poll of of
certainly young LGBT folks I'm not sure
what the percentage would be of of those
who would have known that Stonewall uh
what Stonewall was when it happened and
that there was an anniversary uh and I
think that that's a troubling reality
who knows we haven't done that opinion
poll but my sense would be that you know
not a considerable majority would would
have even known what that history is uh
and if you compare that say to
African-American Young Folks right that
my black students at Harvard who all of
them know what the Montgomery boy bus
boycott was all of them know what Brown
versus Board of Education was right and
they also know py versus Ferguson which
Brown vers Board of Education overturned
and so they know their history uh in
fact You' be hardpressed to find any
student at Harvard University who
doesn't know what the Montgomery Bus
Boycott was or the Brown versus Board of
Education decision and the impact that
it had and the origin that it created or
established for the civil rights
movement and I think the LGBT movement
and its Scholars and its intellectuals
and its activists need to do a better
job of establishing that history and to
in integrating it into the broad public
imagination and moments like the
anniversary of Stonewall give us that
opportunity
